name: Malacca Strait
narrative: The Malacca Strait is the world's busiest shipping chokepoint, handling 25-28% of global maritime trade. Over 90,000 vessels transit annually, carrying crude oil from the Middle East to East Asia. The IMO Traffic Separation Scheme runs ~500 km between One Fathom Bank (Permatang Sedepa) and Horsburgh Lighthouse. Congestion-related delays have increased 15% year-over-year.

name: South China Sea Main Corridor
narrative: The South China Sea main corridor connects Northeast Asia's manufacturing hubs with Southeast Asian distribution centers. An estimated $5.3 trillion in goods traverse this route annually, running west of the Paracel Islands (~111-112°E) and well clear of the Philippine archipelago. Geopolitical tensions add risk premiums of 5-8% on shipping insurance.

name: Sunda Strait
narrative: The Sunda Strait between Java and Sumatra serves as an alternative to Malacca for vessels heading to/from Australia. The strait center sits at approximately 105.88°E, 5.92°S — minimum 24 km wide at its northeastern end. Around 53,000 vessels transit annually, primarily carrying coal, LNG, and iron ore.

name: Lombok Strait
narrative: The Lombok Strait (IMO TSS since July 2019) provides deep-water passage for VLCCs and Capesize bulk carriers too large for the shallow Malacca Strait. Minimum depth 250m — the confirmed strait center is at 115.73°E, 8.77°S. At least 100 vessels/day transit, dominated by Australian iron ore and coal shipments to East Asia.

name: Makassar Strait
narrative: The Makassar Strait (confirmed center: 118.16°E, 1.38°S) runs 800 km between Borneo's east coast (~117-118°E) and Sulawesi's west coast (~119.5°E). A critical corridor for VLCC tankers and bulk carriers, handling ~30% of global seaborne crude oil. Annual traffic exceeds 4,000 vessel transits.

name: Singapore to Jakarta
narrative: The Singapore-Jakarta corridor (478 NM) is one of ASEAN's busiest intra-regional routes. Ships exit via Horsburgh Lighthouse into the South China Sea, then south through the Java Sea center (confirmed: 106.08°E, 3.23°S) to Tanjung Priok. Bilateral trade exceeds $50 billion annually, with 12,000+ vessel movements per year.

name: Singapore to Manila
narrative: The Singapore-Manila route (1,295 NM) traverses the South China Sea via the Palawan Passage — a deep, 35-40 NM wide channel west of Palawan Island (~116-117°E). Ships exit Singapore via Horsburgh Lighthouse and approach Manila Bay from the southwest. Typhoon season (June-November) causes seasonal disruptions averaging 15-20 days annually.

name: Indonesia Nickel Corridor
narrative: The Indonesia Nickel Corridor connects Bahodopi/Morowali (confirmed port: 122.16°E, 2.81°S) with Chinese smelters via the Celebes Sea, east of the Philippines, through the Luzon Strait, and south into the Pearl River Delta. Indonesia controls 48% of global nickel reserves — critical to the EV battery supply chain. Volumes growing 25% annually.

name: Vietnam Coastal
narrative: Vietnam's coastal corridor connects Ho Chi Minh City/Vung Tau (Cai Mep terminal, 107.05°E, 10.41°N) with Hai Phong (106.74°E, 20.91°N), running 20-50 NM offshore to avoid shallow banks. Passes Da Nang (108.22°E, 16.07°N) and into the Gulf of Tonkin. Vietnam's port throughput has grown 12% CAGR, driven by supply chain diversification from China.

name: Palm Oil Corridor
narrative: The Palm Oil Corridor runs westbound through the Malacca Strait from Tanjung Pelepas (103.53°E, 1.36°N) and Port Klang, past Belawan/Medan (98.68°E, 3.78°N) on Sumatra's north coast, across the Andaman Sea and Bay of Bengal to Mumbai/JNPT (72.95°E, 18.95°N). Over 9 million tonnes of crude palm oil flow annually, valued at $8-12 billion.
